welcome.data: Warm-Up Prompt: “Think about websites you've used — have you seen things that stay in place while you scroll? Have you ever seen an image or menu float oddly on a page? Share what you’ve noticed with a partner.”

aim.data: Students will understand the five major CSS position values — static, relative, absolute, fixed, and sticky — and apply them to manipulate element placement in a webpage layout.

review.data: Recall how display values like block, inline, and inline-block affected the flow of content. Ask: “What happened when we added margin or padding to inline elements?”

relevant.data: Mini-lecture and live demo in WebStorm explaining each CSS position type: static, relative, absolute, fixed, and sticky.

interactive.data: Students will experiment with `position` values using the provided starter layout: fixed header, sticky sidebar, relative container with absolute child.

ownership.data: Students create their own layout using at least 3 different position values. Code is pushed to GitHub.io and submitted on Canvas.

resonate.data: Exit Ticket: What’s the difference between absolute and fixed positioning? When might you use sticky instead of fixed?

supplies.data: Computers with WebStorm, internet access, GitHub setup, starter files (position-playground.html, style.css), projector.
